Fig. 1 XRD patterns of fresh NiMo-C-R/SiO2 catalysts (A) calcined at 250, 350, 500 and 650 °C in air, (B) reduced at 600 °C in 10 vol% H2/N2, and (C) calcined at 350 °C in air and subsequently reduced at 400, 500, 600, 650 °C in 10 vol% H2/N2. (D) H2-TPR profiles of the fresh NiMo-C/SiO2 catalysts in (A) as well as NiO/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 as references. (E) UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of (a) NiO; (b) NiO/SiO2; (c) MoO3/SiO2; (d)-(g) NiMo-C/SiO2, C = 250, 350, 500 and 650 °C; (h) NiMoO4. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Effect of calcination temperature on catalytic performance of NiMo-C-600/SiO2 catalysts (C = 250, 350, 500, 650). Reaction conditions: 290 °C, 3 MPa, CO/methanol = 1, GHSV =6720 mL gcat −1 h−1, LHSV(methanol) =6 mL gcat −1 h−1, time on stream =12 h. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Reactivity versus time on stream of NiMo-C-600/SiO2 (C = 250, 350, 500, 650). Reaction conditions: 290 °C, 3 MPa, CO/methanol = 1, GHSV =6720 mL gcat −1 h−1, LHSV(methanol) =6 mL gcat −1 h−1. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Effect of reduction temperature on catalytic performance of NiMo-350-R/SiO2 catalysts (R = 400, 500, 600, 650). Graphical abstract A promising Ni-MoOx bifunctional catalyst for halide-free methanol carbonylation is developed by H2-reduction of NiO-MoO3/SiO2 obtained via facile impregnation method. Catalyst performance is strongly dependent on the calcination/reduction temperature. Over the preferable NiMo-350-600/SiO2 catalyst obtained by calcining at 350 °C and subsequently reducing at 600 °C, a methanol conversion of 4.2 % and acetyls space-time yield of 1.37 mol kgcat −1 h−1 are achieved with 22.1 % selectivity to acetyls at 290 °C and 3 MPa. Co-existence of Ni0 and MoOx (especially MoO2) markedly decreases formation of dimethyl ether (DME) and reversely increases acetyls formation, in nature, due to the catalyst acidity modulation and the partial electron transfer from Ni0 to MoOx that tunes the CO adsorption strength on Ni0 sites. MoO3 and NiMoO4 are both favorable for formation of acetyls and DME whereas the latter mainly accounts for DME formation. MoNi4 alone favors methyl formate formation while together with MoO2 enhancing DME production. Keywords Methanol carbonylation Acetic acid Methyl acetate Bifunctional catalyst Nickel Molybdenum 1 Introduction Acetic acid (AA), as an important commodity chemical with more than 15 megatons global production per year, is widely used in the synthesis of vinyl acetate, acetic anhydride, acetic esters, etc [1,2]. Methanol carbonylation is the main industrial route to produce AA, and co-produced methyl acetate (MA) is also a vital commodity chemical. Besides, compared with other synthesis routes such as ethylene or acetaldehyde oxidation, not only it is an atomic economy reaction, but also the sources of feedstocks are extensive and facile, due to the developed methanol synthesis processes from coal and natural gas [3]. Currently, the two representative industrial routes for homogenous methanol carbonylation to acetyls (AA and MA) are Monsanto [4] and BP Chemicals Cativa™ processes [5], utilizing halide-containing Rh and Ir organic complexes for the reactions respectively. Although these two processes exhibit high activity and selectivity, both of them exist some disadvantages: (1) the use of halides like methyl iodide will form highly corrosive HI during the catalytic cycle, which needs special and expensive reactor materials; (2) the homogenous system and the presence of water cause more costs on separation and purification; (3) noble metal complex catalysts are quite expensive and are also easily deactivated because of leaching. To overcome these problems above-mentioned, many efficient heterogeneous catalysts have been developed by immobilizing active sites on solid support, such as polymers [6,7], activated carbon (AC) [8,9], inorganic oxides [10] and zeolites [10,11]. However, the halide-containing promoter and noble metals are still required, which limits the industrial application of these catalysts. Therefore, researchers pay more attention to developing halide-free and non-noble metal heterogeneous systems with prominent performance and stability. Lee et al. successfully synthesized an organorhodium solid acid catalyst of [Rh(CO)Xantphos]+ n[H3-nPW12O40]n−/SiO2, achieving an optimum STYMA of 4.73 mol kgcat −1 h−1 under mild reaction conditions (1 bar and 200 °C) without halide-containing promoter [12]. Besides, zeolites and supported transition metal catalysts have also made some progress on vapor halide-free methanol carbonylation. H-mordenite (H-MOR), a kind of acidic zeolite with 8- and 12-membered ring (MR) channels, first reported by Fujimoto et al., is capable of realizing methanol carbonylation to AA via Koch-type pathways [13]. They also speculated that the introduced Cu+ cations could accelerate the carbonylation and DME used as a feedstock might be more effective. Corma et al. prepared the Cu-MOR by ion-exchange method to get a higher catalytic activity with 100 % conversion of methanol and 85 % selectivity to acetyls [14]. Nevertheless, at low reaction temperature, H2O derived from dehydration of methanol will compete with methanol for adsorption on active sites, retarding the reaction rate; at the high temperature, Cu-MOR will suffer from rapid deactivation because of coke deposition. Liu et al. reported a stable and selective catalyst based on pyridine-modified H-MOR (Py-MOR) for direct vapor methanol carbonylation with 100 % methanol conversion and 95 % AA selectivity [15]. No obvious deactivation was observed in a 145-h stability test. Although it has an excellent catalytic performance, the high CO to methanol ratio (>50:1) and low STYAA (<3.3 mol kgcat −1 h−1) are still problematic. The supported transition metal (e.g., nickel, copper, cobalt and molybdenum) catalysts also exhibit good catalytic performance. Sulfide CoMo/AC was found to be active for methanol carbonylation, achieving a MA selectivity of 53 % with a low STYMA of 0.15 mol kgcat −1 h−1 [16]. Peng et al. reported that the NiCl2-CuCl2/AC catalyst had a high activity (STYMA =3.2 mol kgcat −1 h−1) of methanol vapor-phase carbonylation even at atmosphere pressure [17]. Meng et al. prepared a series of Cu/TiO2-SiO2 mixed oxide catalysts using the sol-gel method, delivering a favorable STYMA of 1.77 mol kgcat −1 h−1 [18]. So far, the catalytic reaction mechanisms of Rh and Ir complex catalysts have been well studied [19,20]. Taking the Rh complex system as an example, the oxidative addition of CH3I to [Rh(CO)2I2]− forms the methyl complex [CH3Rh(CO)2I3]−, which is the rate-determining step of the cycle. Then, CO migrates and inserts into the RhCH3 bond to form the complex of rhodium acyl [CH3CORh(CO)I3]−, followed by the reductive elimination of this complex to form CH3COI that is quenched by H2O or methanol, ultimately. Besides, the H-MOR or Cu-MOR catalytic mechanism has also been understood deeply. By in-situ FTIR, MAS NMR and DFT calculation, Corma and his group proposed that the incorporated Cu+ can activate CO to form CO*, promoting the rate of CO insertion into methoxy species on adjacent Brønsted acid sites [14,21]. The DFT results suggested that methanol carbonylation preferentially occurs within 8-MR channels, while MTH (Methanol to hydrocarbon) and methanol dehydration to DME reactions mainly proceed in 12-MR channels, which leads to catalyst deactivation [21]. However, there are few studies on the catalytic mechanism of halide-free supported metal catalysts for methanol carbonylation. Christopher et al. demonstrated the influence of dispersed Rh species and support acidity on methanol carbonylation to AA [22]. Meng et al. elucidated that the Cu+ species act not only as metal sites to adsorb CO, but also as Lewis acid sites to promote the adsorption of methanol over the Cu/TiO2-SiO2 composite catalyst [18], which is in accordance with the role of Cu+ in the Cu-MOR for this reaction. As well known, NiO-MoO3 composite oxide is considered to be a potential active component for reactions like hydrodesulfurization [23,24] and the oxidative dehydrogenation of alkane/alcohol [25,26]. Moreover, sulfide or alkali modified NiO-MoO3 catalysts can be employed for CO hydrogenation to oxygenates reaction, which also involves the carbonylation steps when C2+ oxygenates are generated [27]. Accordingly, we speculated that NiO-MoO3 composite oxides and its derived catalysts might be active and selective for halide-free methanol carbonylation to acetyls. Herein, a series of NiO-MoO3/SiO2 catalyst precursors were prepared via stepwise wet-impregnation and subsequent calcination treatment, and the Ni-MoOx/SiO2 catalysts were then obtained by H2-reduction treatment. The effects of calcination and reduction pretreatments were investigated on the catalyst performance in the gas-phase halide-free methanol carbonylation. The preferred catalyst, obtained by calcining at 350 °C and subsequently reducing at 600 °C, achieves 4.2 % methanol conversion and 22.1 % sum selectivity to acetyls with a STYacetyls of 1.37 mol kgcat −1 h−1 at 290 °C and 3 MPa. The performance-relevant properties of the Ni-MoOx/SiO2 catalysts were systematically investigated, using X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV–vis diffusion reflectance spectroscopy (UV–vis DR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscope (SEM), H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and NH3-/CO-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-/CO-TPD). The “structure-property-performance” relationship of such catalysts in this reaction process was discussed deeply. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of NiO-MoO3/SiO2 catalyst were synthesized via stepwise incipient wetness impregnation method. SiO2 (Jinan Xinzheng Chemical, 200 m2 g−1) was utilized as support owing to its inertness and high specific surface area (SSA). Besides, the molar ratio of Ni/Mo was fixed at 1. Typically, Ni(NO3)3⋅6H2O (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. LTD., 98 %) of 0.5056 g was dissolved in 5 mL deionized water and used to impregnate 1 g SiO2, followed by drying at 100 °C overnight; Subsequently, as-obtained samples were incipiently impregnated again with another aqueous solution containing 0.3038 g (NH4)6Mo7O24⋅4H2O (Shanghai No.4 Reagent & H.V. Chemical Limited Company, A.R.) and dried at 100 °C overnight. After that, the resulting samples were heated to appointed temperature at a ramp rate of 2 °C/min and calcined for 2 h in air, obtaining NiO-MoO3/SiO2 precursors (named as NiMo-C/SiO2, where C is the calcination temperature). As-obtained NiMo-C/SiO2 samples were transformed into NiMo-C-R/SiO2 catalysts by reduction with H2 at desired temperature for 2 h, where C is calcination temperature and R is reduction temperature. Taking the NiMo-350-600/SiO2 as an example, the NiO-MoO3/SiO2 obtained by calcining at 350 °C for 2 h was reduced in a 10 vol% H2/N2 mixed gas at 600 °C for 2 h (using a ramp rate of 10 °C/min). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The content of Ni and Mo in the NiMo-C-R/SiO2 catalyst was quantitatively analyzed by the inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) on a USA Thermo IRIS Intrepid IIXSP ICP spectrometer. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured at −196 °C on a BEL-MAX gas adsorption analyzer. All samples were degassed under high vacuum at 300 °C for 6 h before the measurement. The total SSA was calculated from the adsorption branch in the range of relative pressure from 0.05 to 0.3 by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. And the pore-size distribution was determined using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method for the desorption branch. XRD patterns were obtained on a Rigaku Ultra IV diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation at 35 kV and 25 mA in the 2θ scanning range of 10−90° and at scanning rate of 30° min−1. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopies were conducted on a Shimadzu UV-2700 spectrophotometer utilizing barium sulfate as the reference. The catalysts were also characterized by SEM (Hitachi S-4800; Japan). H2-TPR and CO-/NH3-TPD experiments were also carried out on a TP 5080 multi-functional automatic adsorption instrument (Xianquan Industrial and Trading Co., Ltd, China) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), which is connected to a mass spectroscopy measurer (TILON GRP technology limited, Shanghai, China). XPS measurements were performed on an AXIS SUPRA (Kratos, Britain) spectrometer, using a standard Al Kα X-ray source (300 W) and analyzer pass energy of 40.0 eV. The binding energies were calibrated relative to the C1s line at 284.8 eV. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The vapor phase methanol carbonylation was evaluated in a fixed-bed stainless steel reactor with an inner diameter of 8 mm at 1−4 MPa system pressure. The catalyst sample (0.5 g) was packed into the reactor, and the catalyst was reduced at 400−650 °C in a 10 vol% H2/N2 mixed gas flow (40 mL min−1) for 2 h. After cooling the catalyst bed down to the desired temperature (in the range of 250–300 °C) in N2 flow (30 mL min−1), the gas flow was then switched to CO (99.99 %) with desired flow. After system pressure was raised to appointed value, anhydrous methanol (99.5 %) was quantitatively pumped into an evaporator (200 °C) and fully mixed with CO there before passing through the catalyst bed. The total gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) including CO and vaporized methanol (approximately regarded as ideal gas) was initially fixed at 6720 mL gcat −1 h−1. The product effluent was analyzed using an online-gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with an HP-PLOT/Q capillary column connected to a flame ionization detector. The gas line connecting the reactor outlet with the GC was heated to 120 °C using heating tape to avoid product condensation. The conversion based on methanol and product selectivity were thus calculated using the standard normalization method on the basis of carbon atom balance as follows: Conv methanol (%) = 1- A methanol out × f methanol out ∑ C i × n i + A methanol out × f methanol out ×100% S el i (%) = C i × n i ∑ C i × n i ×100% S el acetyls (%) = A AA × f AA + 2×A MA × f MA ∑ C i × n i ×100% STY i = X meth anol × S i × LHSV methanol × ρ methanol M methanol LHSV = F methanol m catalyst GHSV = 24000 × LHSV methanol × ρ methanol M methanol + F CO m catalyst Where Ci is the number molar of carbon atoms of product i, and ni is the number of moles of product i (i = CH4, C2H4, C2H6, C3H6, C3H8, HCOOCH3 (MF), CH3OCH3 (DME), CH3COOCH3 (MA), and CH3COOH (AA), respectively). M and ρ are the relative molecular mass and the density of methanol, Fmethanol and FCO represent the flow rates of gaseous methanol and CO, and mcatalyst represents the loading of catalyst, respectively. We adopted carbon mass balance based on methanol to calculate the degree of methanol decomposition and/or carbon deposition in this reaction, and the carbon mass balance of 94∼102 % was obtained. It means that under the extreme conditions, only 6% methanol generates COx and/or carbon deposition. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst structural, textural and morphological properties In Fig. 1 , XRD phase evolution and reducibility of the catalyst samples are illustrated against the catalyst calcination/reduction temperatures. For samples that have merely been calcined, as shown in Fig. 1A, their XRD phases are subject to the sample calcination temperature. When calcining at 250 °C (i.e., NiMo-250/SiO2), very weak diffraction patterns of both (NH4)Ni2Mo2O8(OH)⋅H2O (JCPDS No. 52-0168) and NiO (2θ of 37.1°, 43.1°, and 62.6°; JCPDS No. 89-7130) except SiO2 support (showing a big bulge peak at 2θ of 15°-35°) are observed. When calcining at 350 °C, the NiO diffraction patterns become strong slightly and no Mo-containing phases are detected in association with the disappearance of (NH4)Ni2Mo2O8(OH)⋅H2O phase. In contrast, very strong diffraction patterns of NiO and MoO3 are detected on both the NiO/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 after calcining at 350 °C. In combining this information with the fact of only very weak NiO diffraction detected on the NiMo-350/SiO2, it is believed that coexistence of NiO and MoO3 is extremely advantageous for their high dispersion. Indeed, some studies also reported that molybdenum oxide species appears as highly dispersed state at the surface of SiO2 [28,29], and the site isolation effect of MoO3 was observed when doping with another transition metal [28,30]. Nevertheless, after calcining at 500 °C (i.e., NiMo-500/SiO2), α-NiMoO4 (JCPDS No. 86-0361) and β-NiMoO4 (JCPDS No. 45-0142) other than MoO3 phases emerge while NiO phases completely disappear. Moreover, calcining at 650 °C markedly facilitates the crystallization of NiMoO4 compounds (especially β-NiMoO4) evidenced by their narrow and relatively strong diffraction patterns for the NiMo-650/SiO2 sample. As shown in Fig. 1E, the UV–vis diffuse reflectance (UV–vis DR) spectroscopy is also conducted to further identify the structures of the nickel and molybdenum species on the NiMo-C/SiO2 catalysts as well as the spectra of NiO, NiO/SiO2, MoO3/SiO2 and NiMoO4 for comparison. For pure NiO, a strong ligand field transition at around 410 nm should be ascribed to the O3 band (3A2g-3T1(P)) of Ni2+ ions in an octahedral environment [31]. The absorption bands in the region of 200−800 nm (like 380, 405, 420 and 460 nm) were detected in pure NiO; while in the case of NiO/SiO2, the bands were changed into a broad peak at 230−370 nm, indicating that the coordination environment of the Ni2+ in NiO/SiO2 and pure NiO are quite different, which may be due to the formation of highly isolated Ni2+ and oligomeric species on SiO2. In MoO3/SiO2, the only absorption in the range of 200−400 nm is observed, because of the ligand-metal charge transfer transition (LMCT) from O2− to Mo6+. Specifically, the absorption band at 260−275 nm can be ascribed to the isolated surface MoO4 species, while the band at 280−300 nm is assigned to the poly-molybdenum oxide species which is dominating [32,33]. A shoulder at around 330 nm suggests the presence of bulk MoO3 phase in the MoO3/SiO2, in line with the results of XRD (Fig. 1A). For NiMoO4, strong LMCT bands of O2−－Mo6+ at 215 and 275 nm belong to the characteristics of the tetrahedrally coordinated MoO4 species, whereas in long wavelength region, an obvious band at 438 nm and a shoulder at around 710 nm, can be assigned to the absorption of octahedrally coordinated Ni2+ ions [33]. The spectra of NiMo-C/SiO2 with different calcination temperatures are shown in (d)-(g) of Fig. 1E. Clearly, the NiMo-250/SiO2 displays a quite similar absorption spectra to NiMoO4 (215, 275, 438, 710 nm) even though the band at 507 nm is weaker, indicating that the coordination environment of Ni2+ and Mo6+ in (NH4)Ni2Mo2O8(OH)⋅H2O phase is identical to that of NiMoO4. For the NiMo-350/SiO2, the typical absorption bands at 438, 507 and 710 nm of octahedrally coordinated Ni2+ species in NiMoO4 are not obvious, whereas the isolated Ni2+ and/or Mo6+ (260−275 nm) species is visible. Besides, the absorption band at 280−400 nm becomes more pronounced compared with that of NiMoO4, which may be attributed to the presence of poly-molybdenum oxide species (280−300 nm) and bulk MoO3 species (∼335 nm) as well as bulk NiO (340 and 380 nm). The appearance of the band at 468 nm further implies the existence of bulk NiO, which is accordance with the XRD results that Ni2+ and Mo6+ species are highly dispersed over the NiMo-350/SiO2 (Fig. 1A). With the increase in the calcination temperature to 500 and 650 °C, besides the strengthened absorption of NiMoO4 (215, 275, 438, 710 nm), the absorption band at 300−400 nm becomes stronger with red shift, indicating the formation of more bulk MoO3 and NiO species, which cannot be distinguished by XRD (Fig. 1A). Fig. 1B shows the XRD phase evolution of the samples in Fig. 1A after H2-reduction at 600 °C. A typical diffraction peak at 26.0° of MoO2 (JCPDS No. 86-0135) is detected in all bimetallic catalysts, whereas MoNi4 alloy (2θ of 43.5°, 50.4°, 51.2° and 74.7°; JCPDS No. 65-5480), Ni (2θ of 44.3°, 51.7° and 76.1°; JCPDS No. 89-7128) and NiO are all distinguishable after peak fitting from 41° to 47°. Notably, the nickel molybdenum nitride Ni2Mo3N (JCPDS No. 89-4564) is detected only in the NiMo-250-600/SiO2 sample. The reduction of MoO3/SiO2 is stopped at MoO2/SiO2 during H2-reduction at 600 °C, whereas most of Mo6+ is reduced to Mo0 and is alloyed with Ni0 to form MoNi4 in all the NiMo-C-600/SiO2 catalysts (Ni2Mo3N is simultaneously formed in NiMo-250-600/SiO2). A reasonable explanation is that Ni0 facilitates the deep reduction of MoOx species, which is verified by the H2-TPR later. Notably, the NiMo-350-600/SiO2 delivers stronger diffraction peaks of MoO2 and Ni0 compared to the other NiMo-C-600/SiO2 samples, most likely due to the high dispersion of NiO and MoO3 for the NiMo-350/SiO2 precursor (Fig. 1A). In addition, some NiO is always detected in all the NiMo-C-600/SiO2 catalysts while stronger NiO XRD peak is observed on both the NiMo-500-600/SiO2 and NiMo-650-600/SiO2 (the inset in Fig. 1B) compared to the NiMo-350-600/SiO2. This observation is tightly linked with the clear formation of NiMoO4 compounds on their corresponding precursors of NiMo-500/SiO2 and NiMo-650/SiO2 (Fig. 1A). As previously reported by Smirnov et al., the NiMoO4/SiO2 is hardly reduced and the NiMoOx [NiOx-(MoO3)1-x] species with NiO-type structure is still detected even after H2-reduction at 570 °C [34]. Fig. 1C shows the XRD pattern evolution of the NiMo-350/SiO2 samples (after calcining at 350 °C) against the H2-reduction temperature. In case of reducing at 400 °C, only Ni0 and NiO phases were detected without any detectable formation of MoO2 and MoNi4. The MoO2 and MoNi4 diffraction peaks are detected in association with almost disappearance of NiO after reducing at 500 °C, while their formation is promoted with elevating the H2-reduction temperature to 600 °C. However, further increasing the H2-reduction temperature just to 650 °C, new compound of Ni2Mo3N is formed (because of using 10 vol% H2/N2 mixture for reduction treatment) and well crystalized while the MoO2 disappears completely but with some remaining Ni0 and MoNi4. However, Ni2Mo3N is not active phase for carbonylation, which is confirmed by the subsequent comparative experiments (discussed in Model catalyst). Reducibility of the NiMo-C/SiO2 was investigated by H2-TPR as well as NiO/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 as references, with the results shown in Fig. 1D. The NiO/SiO2 shows a H2 consumption profile with multi-overlapped peaks from 290 to 500 °C, due to the non-uniformity with respect to NiO dispersion and/or interaction between NiO and SiO2. The MoO3/SiO2 shows a H2-TPR profile with two clearly separated reduction peaks, being assigned to Mo6+-to-Mo4+ (430–630 °C) and Mo4+-to-Mo0 (630–830 °C) respectively. However, it is worth noting that the first peak has a shoulder centered at around 560 °C, which is ascribed to the reduction of poly MoOx species that has been confirmed by UV–vis DR (Fig. 1E). Compared with the isolated MoOx species (centered at around 525 °C), the poly MoOx species is more difficult to be reduced [35]. Clearly, the NiMo-C/SiO2 samples deliver new H2-TPR profiles not overlaying the profiles of NiO/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2. For the NiMo-250/SiO2, nickel and molybdenum presents dominantly in (NH4)Ni2Mo2O8(OH)·H2O compound, which accounts for a H2-TPR profile quite different to those for the three others. The H2-TPR profiles of the NiMo-350/SiO2, NiMo-500/SiO2, and NiMo-650/SiO2, can be deconvoluted into four peaks. In combining this observation with their phase compositions revealed by XRD (Fig. 1A) as well as UV–vis DR (Fig. 1E), the H2 consumption peak centered at 390 °C is reasonably assigned to the NiO reduction and its amount declines markedly with rising the calcination temperature from 350 to 650 °C, which is consistent with the observation of gradual transformation of NiO into NiMoO4 (Fig. 1A). The H2 consumption peaks at around 450 °C and 500 °C are undoubtedly ascribed to the cascade reduction of isolated or oligomeric Mo6+ (Mo6+ to Mo4+ at 450 °C and Mo4+ to Mo0 at 500 °C) for the NiMo-350/SiO2 but to the reduction of NiMoO4 for the NiMo-500/SiO2 and NiMo-650/SiO2; almost equivalent area of these two peaks for the NiMo-500/SiO2 and NiMo-650/SiO2 solidly evidences that the assignment of these two peaks to the reduction of NiMoO4 is correct, because the reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0 and Mo6+ to Mo4+ at 450 °C will consume equal amount of H2 for further reduction of Mo4+ to Mo0. Most notably, in comparison with the MoO3/SiO2, the reduction of Mo-containing compounds in all NiMo-C/SiO2 becomes much easier. A rational explanation is that formed Ni0 serves as catalyst to facilitate H2 activation thereby markedly lowering the cationic Mo reduction. But, reduction of cationic Ni in NiMoO4 becomes slightly difficult compared to the NiO/SiO2, because of the higher NiO bond energy in nickel molybdate accordingly [28]. In addition, a weak H2 consumption peak appears at 660−680 °C for the NiMo-350/SiO2, NiMo-500/SiO2, and NiMo-650/SiO2, likely assignable to the second stage of the reduction of bulk MoOx (detected by UV–vis DR) interacted weakly with the Ni0 (i.e., poor catalytic reduction of such MoO3). Moreover, the total H2 consumption amount deduced from H2-TPR results shows a decline evolution with increasing the calcination temperature from 250 to 650 °C (Table S1). A possible explanation is that calcining at high temperature markedly strengthens the interaction between NiO and support thereby leading to surface solid reaction to form some Ni-containing compounds difficultly reducible below 830 °C. As previously noted [36], especially, this process can be enhanced in the presence of MoOx. The morphological and textural properties of the NiMo-C-R/SiO2 catalysts are characterized by SEM and N2 adsorption-desorption isothermals, with the results shown in Fig. S1 and Table S2. Clearly, the catalysts all present the amorphous surface morphology with irregular particle shape and mesoporous feature evidenced by the typical isotherms of type IV with the steep and narrow hysteresis loop (Fig. S1). Besides, they all possess similar SSA, pore volume and average pore diameter (Table S2). 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Effect of calcination temperature We initially investigated the effect of calcination temperature on the methanol carbonylation performance of the NiMo-C-600/SiO2 catalysts (fixing H2-reduction temperature at 600 °C), with the results shown in Fig. 2 . Clearly, the NiMo-350-600/SiO2 obtained by calcining at 350 °C is promising for the title reaction, achieving the highest acetyls selectivity of 22.1 % at 4.2 % methanol conversion with the by-products selectivity of 34.7 % DME, 32.3 % MF, 8.8 % CH4, and 2.0 % HC2+ (C2-C3 hydrocarbons). The NiMo-250-600/SiO2 (calcining at 250 °C) achieves 14.8 % selectivity to acetyls at a methanol conversion of 4.6 %. Raising the calcination temperature from 350 to 500 °C improves the methanol conversion to 6.5 % but leads to remarkable decrease of acetyls selectivity to 10.8 % in association with sharp increase of DME selectivity up to 75.8 %. Such evolution trend is more pronounced with further increasing the calcination temperature up to 650 °C; methanol conversion increases to 12.2 % as well as DME selectivity up to 93.1 % but with further decline of not only acetyls selectivity to only 2.8 % but also the selectivity of MF, CH4, and HC2+ to 1.1 %, 2.7 %, and 0.3 %. In Fig. 3 , conversion and selectivity for the methanol carbonylation using NiMo-C-600/SiO2 catalysts is plotted against the time on stream (TOS). The catalysts of NiMo-250-600/SiO2, NiMo-500-600/SiO2, and NiMo-650-600/SiO2 show similar performance evolution within 12-h testing, that is, conversion and selectivity of products except DME decline fast in first 4−5 hours and gradually slips into a plateau. Exceptionally, a high acetyls selectivity of around 22 % is achieved over the NiMo-350-600/SiO2 and is held throughout the entire test, whereas the conversion and selectivity to other products over this catalyst show evolution with TOS similar to the three others. As discussed in posterior section, this observation is linked with their catalytic performance relevant properties that are dependent on the catalyst calcination temperature. Even though a highest acetyls selectivity of 22.1 % can be obtained over the preferable NiMo-350-600/SiO2, it still presents a high DME selectivity (34.7 %). Thus, here comes a question: does the formed DME also participate in the carbonylation process to generate acetyls? To figure it out, the comparative experiment of DME as feed to replace methanol was carried out, and the result was shown in Table S5. Apparently, DME has almost no conversion (0.4 %) and no acetyls product is detected under the same reaction conditions (only a few hydrocarbon species). Therefore, it is convinced that the possibility of a consecutive reaction, in which the formed DME converted to acetyls, is excluded. 3.2.2 Effect of reduction temperature To explore the effect of reduction temperature on the catalyst performance, the catalyst precursor of NiMo-350/SiO2 was reduced at varied temperatures and tested in the methanol carbonylation, with the results shown in Fig. 4 . With the increase in the reduction temperature from 400 to 650 °C, methanol conversion shows a downward trend as well as the DME selectivity, whereas the selectivity to acetyls and MF shows an upward evolution. The selectivity to CH4 and HC2+ seems not sensitive to the catalyst reduction temperature in the studied range, whereas slightly more CH4 and HC2+ are formed over the NiMo-350-600/SiO2 compared to the three others. From the perspective of maximizing the acetyls productivity, the NiMo-350-600/SiO2 prevails over the three others, achieving a STYacetyls of 1.37 mol kgcat −1 h−1 at 22.1 % sum selectivity to acetyls with a methanol conversion of 4.2 %. On the basis of above results, it is clear that calcination and reduction treatment at appropriate temperature is essential to maximize the yield of acetyls by suppressing the formation of DME and MF to a great extent. 3.2.3 Effects of reaction conditions The effects of reaction conditions on catalytic performance were investigated systematically using the NiMo-350-600/SiO2 catalyst, including reaction temperature, total pressure, total gas hourly space velocity (GHSV, see calculation method in Experimental section) and molar ratio of CO to methanol, with the results shown in Fig. 5 . Fig. 5A shows the reaction temperature dependent conversion and product selectivity for the methanol carbonylation for a feed with CO/methanol ratio of 1/1 at 3 MPa using a total GHSV of 6720 mL gcat −1 h−1. Clearly, elevated temperature facilitates methanol conversion and the formation of DME as well as CH4 and HC2+ but is unfavorable for the formation of acetyls and MF. Increasing the reaction temperature from 250 to 330 °C improves the methanol conversion from 1.8 to 8.2 % while leading to a marked decline of acetyls selectivity from 23.5 to 9.8% as well as MF from 44.8 to 12.2%. In Fig. 5B, conversion and product selectivity for the methanol carbonylation, testing at 290 °C and 3 MPa using GHSV of 6720 mL gcat −1 h−1, is plotted against CO/methanol molar ratio. With the CO/methanol molar ratio increasing from 0.5 to 11, the methanol conversion increases from 3.3 to 6.4%, whereas the acetyls selectivity achieves a maximum value of 19.1 % at CO/methanol molar ratio of 1/1 then declines slightly with further increasing the ratio. But the yield of acetyl species (methanol conversion times acetyls selectivity) shows an increased trend. The effect of total GHSV on the catalyst performance for this reaction was addressed by fixing the other variables (290 °C, CO/methanol = 1/1, 3 MPa), showing a continuous decline of methanol conversion from 8.2 to 3.2% with increasing the GHSV in the studied range (Fig. 5C), likely due to the less contact time of reactants. In this course, the acetyls selectivity slightly goes up from 13.3 to 20.0 % at GHSV of 5040 mL gcat −1 h−1 then holds steady, while the CH4 plus HC2+ selectivity declines from 40.4 to 10.3 %. On the contrary, the DME and MF selectivity is markedly increased from 29.4 to 36.6 % and 16.9 to 33.4 % with increasing the GHSV, respectively. Fig. 5D shows the reaction results as a function of reaction pressure with other variables unchanged (290 °C, CO/methanol = 1/1, GHSV of 6720 mL gcat −1 h−1). As can be seen, with increasing the reaction pressure from 1 to 4 MPa, the methanol conversion is improved from 4.4 to 5.8 % but the distribution of products does not change a lot. Considering the balance between conversion and the target product selectivity for a maximum STYacetyls, optimal reaction conditions in the studied range are 290 °C, GHSV of 6720 mL gcat −1 h−1, and 3 MPa, for a feed with CO/methanol molar ratio of 1/1. Additionally, the comparison of our catalyst with other reported ones for methanol carbonylation to acetyls is displayed in Table S4. 3.3 Insight into the synergistic catalysis 3.3.1 Correlation between XRD phases and catalyst activity/selectivity To reveal the structure-property-performance relationship of the NiMo-C-R/SiO2 catalysts for the methanol carbonylation, the used catalysts after 12-h testing were all characterized using XRD, with the results shown in Fig. 6 and Table 1 . As we can see from Fig. 6A, MoO2 is detectable in the used NiMo-C-600/SiO2 catalysts except the NiMo-500-600/SiO2 and NiMo-650-600/SiO2. After deconvolving the multi-peaks at 40−47°, MoNi4, NiO, and Ni0 are clearly distinguishable in all used NiMo-C-600/SiO2 catalysts. Notably, according to the literature, the hardly reduced NiMoOx species (the main peak at around 42.5°) at the reduction temperature of 600 °C are also distinguished, whose diffraction peaks are displaced toward distant angles (low angles in fact) with respect to NiO [34]. To further confirm the co-existence of NiMoOx and NiO in the used NiMo-C-600/SiO2 catalysts, a typical sample of used NiMo-350-600/SiO2 was reduced at 500 °C again in H2 flow for 3 h and probed by XRD (Fig. S2). By comparison of the used NiMo-350-600/SiO2 before and after H2 reduction again, the intensity of the peaks at around 36.9, 37.1, 41.3 and 43.1° decrease while the peak at around 43.5° remarkably increases, which is originated from the reduction of MoO2 and NiO to form MoNi4. This observation indicates that NiO still exists in the catalyst sample even after experiencing 12-h reaction. Combining this information with the fact that the hardly reduced NiMoOx at 36.5 and 42.5° still exists (stronger than NiO) after reduction again as well as the presence of MoO2 and Ni0 in the used NiMo-350-600/SiO2, it is safe to say that NiO, NiMoOx, MoO2, Ni0 and MoNi4 are co-existed in the catalyst during the reaction. Among these Ni- and/or Mo-containing phases, however, which phases are active and selective for this reaction is still not clear. Moreover, as shown in Table 1, the strong NiMoOx, NiO and MoO2, moderate MoNi4 and weak Ni diffraction peaks are detectable for the used NiMo-250-600/SiO2. Except the weak Ni and MoNi4 peaks, the preferable NiMo-350-600/SiO2 after 12-h testing presents stronger MoO2 and weaker NiMoOx peaks compared with other used NiMo-C-600/SiO2 catalysts (Fig. 6A and Table 1). This observation shows a positive correlation with its better catalytic performance than the others. It is rational to regard MoO2 as one of the active phases for methanol carbonylation process to obtain high acetyls selectivity, while NiMoOx may go against the formation of target products or be a spectator. It should be pointed out that the synergistic catalysis between Ni (or MoNi4) and MoO2 should also be considered because the dual-site is fairly common in bimolecular catalytic reactions [22,37,38], which will be discussed in next section. Dominant phase of NiMoOx as well as moderate MoNi4 and NiO are detected for the used MoO2-free NiMo-500-600/SiO2 and NiMo-650-600/SiO2, which is in agreement with their low acetyls selectivity and high DME selectivity (Fig. 2). This observation in turn indicates that the MoO2 plays a key role in the methanol carbonylation while the NiMoOx is mainly responsible for producing DME. Fig. 6B and Table 1 also show that only the weak NiO phase remains over the used NiMo-350-400/SiO2, and MoOx (4 < x ≤ 6) species (measured by XPS later) is still undetectable, which might be highly dispersed. Over this catalyst, high DME selectivity and high methanol conversion (Fig. 4) are obtained, meaning that NiO and/or MoOx (4 < x ≤ 6) are active for the formation of DME. In the used NiMo-350-500/SiO2, apparent MoO2 phase is detected as well as a little amount of MoNi4, NiO, NiMoOx and Ni0 phases. Although the methanol conversion of such used NiMo-350-500/SiO2 decreases (Fig. 4), the emergence of MoO2 enables the catalyst with higher acetyls selectivity and lower DME selectivity in comparison with the NiMo-350-400/SiO2. Besides, for the used NiMo-350-500/SiO2, the increased MF selectivity (Fig. 4) indicates that MoO2 is also active for producing MF (which is proved by the following model catalyst). Stronger MoO2 diffraction peaks are detected as well as Ni0, MoNi4, NiMoOx and NiO peaks in the preferred NiMo-350-600/SiO2 catalyst after 12-h reaction. According to the reaction results in Fig. 2 and XRD patterns in Fig. 6A for the NiMo-500-600/SiO2 and NiMo-650-600/SiO2 catalysts, the NiMoOx favors the DME selectivity. Notably, whereas NiMoOx is apparently detected in used NiMo-350-600/SiO2, the DME selectivity is almost unchanged, remaining at 34.7 % after 12-h evaluation (Fig. 4). This observation, together with the fact that NiO, MoOx (4 < x ≤ 6), and NiMoOx are favorable for DME formation, is promissory of a synergistic interaction between MoO2 and Ni (or MoNi4). Only Ni2Mo3N phase is visible in the used NiMo-350-650/SiO2 that shows a high MF selectivity (Fig. 4), indicating that Ni2Mo3N is mainly responsible for the MF formation. On the basis of above analysis and discussion, we can tentatively say that: (1) MoO2 is a decisive component with relatively high activity and selectivity for the methanol carbonylation to form acetyls; (2) NiO, MoOx (4 < x ≤ 6) and NiMoOx are favorable for the formation of DME; (3) Ni2Mo3N is active for the formation of MF; considering that this compound phase is not formed in our preferable NiMo-350-600/SiO2 catalyst, its effect will be not deliberately discussed. Despite above findings, the roles of Ni and MoNi4 in tuning the catalyst reactivity are still unclear, which needs to be revealed. To accomplish this goal, a series of model catalysts were prepared and tested in this reaction, which will be analyzed and discussed next. 3.3.2 Model catalysts A series of mono-component catalysts of NiO/SiO2, Ni/SiO2, Ni2Mo3N/SiO2, MoNi4/SiO2, NiMoO4/SiO2, MoO3/SiO2, and MoO2/SiO2 were prepared and tested in the methanol carbonylation at 290 °C, with the results shown in Table 2 and the XRD patterns in Fig. S3. Notably, the pure SiO2 support was also tested as a reference. Clearly, the pure SiO2 is in active for this reaction although a few weak acid sites were detected on it (see 3.3.3). The NiO/SiO2 is not so active (1.3 % conversion) but achieves a pleasing acetyls selectivity of 21.2 % and a 46.8 % selectivity to MF, whereas the Ni/SiO2 is almost inert and non-selective for this reaction: 0.7 % conversion and 1.9 % acetyls selectivity. Similar to the Ni/SiO2, the alloy catalysts of both Ni2Mo3N/SiO2 and MoNi4/SiO2 are still unfavorable for the acetyls formation but with improved activity while they are in charge of the formation of MF. Over the NiMoO4/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2, improved acetyls selectivity of 17.4 % and 13.7 % is achieved whereas DME becomes the dominant product (>72 % selectivity) with high methanol conversion of 8.1 % and 7.6 %. Notably, the MoO2/SiO2 shows a performance, with respect to methanol conversion and product distribution, seemingly a bit closer to that of the NiMo-350-600/SiO2. Clearly, as far as acetyls are considered as target product, MoO2 and NiO as well as NiMoO4 are quite selective; besides, MoO2 and NiO are also highly selective to MF but NiMoO4 to DME. The reaction test results over the contrastive catalysts basically evidence our speculation for active phase in XRD analysis (Fig. 6). Moreover, two dual-component catalysts of MoNi4-MoO2/SiO2 and Ni-MoO2/SiO2 as well as SiO2+NiMo-350-600 (mechanically mixed NiMo-350-600 up with SiO2) were tailored and tested in this reaction, with their catalytic results shown in Table 2 and the XRD patterns in Fig. S3. Interestingly, the Ni-MoO2/SiO2 catalyst achieves close-to-optimal performance, with 4.8 % methanol conversion and acetyls/MF/DME selectivity of 21.6 %/22.6 %/47.4 %, being comparable to those obtained over our preferable NiMo-350-600/SiO2 catalyst. However, introduction of MoNi4 into MoO2/SiO2 results in a sharp and marked decrease of the selectivity to MF and acetyls but a sharp increase of the selectivity to DME. Above results suggest that Ni-doping enables the MoO2/SiO2 with enhanced activity but almost not affects its product selectivity. A possible explanation is that alliance between Ni and MoO2 generates synergistic catalysis, which is a guarantee to promote the carbonylation rate and simultaneously slow down the rates of dehydration and dehydrogenation of methanol. Besides, the carbonylation performance of the mechanically mixed SiO2+NiMo-350-600 (methanol conversion of 3.2 %, acetyls selectivity of 23.9 %) is close to the optimal NiMo-350-600/SiO2 (methanol conversion of 4.2 %, acetyls selectivity of 22.1 %). However, the DME/MF selectivity of 60.0 %/9.9 % is higher/lower than that of the optimal NiMo-350-600/SiO2 (34.7 %/32.3 %). Without dispersing on SiO2, the NiO particle was directly supported on MoO3, leading to formation of more MoNi4 and MoO2 species (the stronger diffraction intensities compared to those of the optimal NiMo-350-600/SiO2) (Fig. S3). As clearly known in Table 2, more MoO2 facilitates the acetyls selectivity whereas the co-existence of MoNi4-MoO2 (e.g., MoNi4-MoO2/SiO2) is favorable for methanol to DME. In combining such information with the fact of inactiveness of SiO2 for this reaction, we thus think that SiO2 herein is not involved in the reaction and merely serves as support for dispersing active components. 3.3.3 Acidity feature Previous studies have unveiled that the type and strength of acid sites on catalyst surface have a great influence on methanol and CO adsorption [18,22,39,40]. To explore the acidity feature of our catalysts, NH3-TPD was performed for the NiMo-C-R/SiO2 as well as some model catalysts, with the results shown in Fig. 7 and Table 3 . As shown in Fig. 7A for the model catalysts, the desorption peaks at 50–200, 200–300 and 300−550 °C are attributed to NH3 chemisorbed on weak, moderate and strong acid sites, respectively. The pure SiO2 support offers a NH3 desorption peak around 100 °C, originated from the weak acidity of Si−OH on SiO2 surface. The relatively strong asymmetric NH3-desorption peaks ranging from 70 to 300 °C are found on the NiO/SiO2, Ni/SiO2, Ni2Mo3N/SiO2 and MoNi4/SiO2, being assignable to the weak and moderate acid sites. For the alloy catalysts, Ni2Mo3N/SiO2 and MoNi4/SiO2 both possess a certain of surface acidity but they still keep high MF selectivity (Table 2), and hence we speculate that methoxy species formed by methanol is more likely to be transformed into formaldehyde species on the alloy particles via further dehydrogenation, which is the rate-determining step of methanol dehydrogenation to MF [41,42]. Based on the results in Table 2, we knew that NiMoO4 and MoO3 have a high activity to selectively produce DME. To further investigate the effects of surface acid density and type on the catalytic performance, we first calculated the NH3 content corresponding to the unit peak area by quantitatively pulsing highly pure NH3, then the NH3 desorption amount on the corresponding acid sites were obtained by integrating the peak areas (at 50–200, 200–300, 300−500 °C, respectively). Combining this information with the acidity results quantitatively deduced from Fig. 7 as shown in Table 3, due to the Lewis acidity of Mo6+ species, plenty of acid sites are observed on NiMoO4/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2 with the total acid site density (mainly the weak and moderate) of 469.8 and 479.3 μmolNH3 gcat −1, respectively, higher than those of other mono-component catalysts. That is probably the main cause for their high DME yield (methanol conversion times DME selectivity; Table 2). Besides the weak and moderate acid sites, in contrast, MoO2/SiO2 also provides a broad peak centered at 417 °C, which is attributed to strong acid sites of Mo−OH on MoO2 surface formed by MoO3 after hydrogen pretreatment [43]. Analogous to heteropoly acid catalysts, the strong acid sites (147.2 μmolNH3 gcat −1) of MoO2/SiO2 primarily account for the further dissociation of adsorbed methoxy species on MoO2 surface into CHx species and subsequent methanation and chain propagation, in accordance with its higher hydrocarbon selectivity (Table 2) [44–46]. Among the dual-component model catalysts, the MoNi4-MoO2/SiO2 has much higher weak acid site density (678.2 μmolNH3 gcat −1) than that (396.3 μmolNH3 gcat −1) of the preferred NiMo-350-600/SiO2 thereby leading to a higher activity and DME selectivity. For the Ni-MoO2/SiO2, it possesses an acidity feature quite similar with our preferable NiMo-350-600/SiO2 catalyst, being in accord with their comparable catalytic performance (Table 2). Interestingly, the Ni-MoOx catalysts have higher acid site density (several folds) compared with the mono-component catalysts, except for the catalyst reduced at 650 °C (Table 3), indicating that the interaction between Ni and Mo species obviously increases the surface acid density over the Ni-MoOx catalysts, and it can be tuned via changing the pretreatment conditions. In Fig. 7B-C, the NH3-TPD profiles of NiMo-C-R/SiO2 were recorded against catalyst calcination and reduction temperatures. As shown in Fig. 7B and Table 3, with the increase in the calcination temperature from 250 to 650 °C, the weak acid site density (Table 3) shows a “V”-shape evolution, quite consistent with the evolution of DME selectivity against the calcination temperature (Fig. 2). There is a quadratic function relationship between the STYDME and weak acid site density (Fig. 8 A), which is characteristic of the bimolecular reaction on the contiguous acidic sites [22,39]. Besides, in Fig. 8C, a linear positive correlation is found when the STY of hydrocarbon including CH4 and HC2+ (STYHC) is regarded as a function of strong acid site density, confirming that the strong acid sites are also responsible for the formation of HC. As we can see from Fig. 7C and Table 3, the total acid site density (especially the weak acid site) shows a sharp decline with increasing the catalyst reduction treatment temperature, while the density of moderate and strong acid sites is in a volcano shape variation in which top point appears at the reduction temperature of 600 °C (i.e., NiMo-350-600/SiO2). Over such NiMo-350-R/SiO2 catalysts, similarly, the quadratic relationship between STYDME and weak acid site density are also observed as well as the linear correlation between STYHC and strong acid site density (Fig. 8B,D). 3.3.4 Electron interaction We know that Ni-doped MoO2 (such as Ni-MoO2/SiO2) is dominantly contributed to the promising activity and acetyls selectivity of the NiMo-350-600 catalyst (Table 2). But it seems unable to be simply ascribed to the acidity feature tuned by Ni-MoOx interaction (Fig. 7 and Table 3). For instance, both Ni-MoO2/SiO2 and NiMo-350-600/SiO2 show almost equivalent acidity feature including acid density and acid strength, whereas obvious discrepancy between the product distribution still presents over both of them (Table 2). This is probably due to the electron interaction between Ni and MoOx species, which is investigated using XPS method. Unfortunately, due to the difficulty of the in-situ XPS experiments under reaction conditions and the significant structural change of the used catalyst (Fig. 6), the obtained surface information seems to be irregular. Therefore, the reduced catalysts were chosen to be studied. The Ni 2p spectra of the NiMo-350-R/SiO2 (R = 400, 500, 600, 650 °C) with the corresponding peak fittings are displayed in Fig. 9 A. The peaks at binding energy (B.E.) of 852.9, 855.7 (± 0.1), 858.5 and 861.7 eV are assigned to Ni0 2p3/2 and Ni2+ 2p3/2, and their satellites, respectively [47,48]. It should be noted that the NiMo-350-400/SiO2 and NiMo-350-500/SiO2 show a Ni2+ 2p3/2 B.E. of 856.0∼856.1 eV, being much higher than that (855.3 eV) for the Ni/SiO2. In these two cases, on the surface of such two samples Ni2+ is most likely presented in the form of NiMoOx complex, because of only partial reduction of Mo6+ to Mo5+/Mo4+ at and below 500 °C (see Fig. 9B). Moreover, up-shifted Ni0 2p3/2 B.E. on both catalyst surface is also observed in comparison with the Ni/SiO2: 852.9 eV vs. 852.6 eV. With further increase in the reduction temperature from 500 to 600 °C, the B.E. of Ni2+ 2p3/2 decreases from 856.0 to 855.6 eV, whereas the B.E. of Ni0 2p3/2 maintains still at 852.9 eV but with an enhancement of its peak intensity. The up-shifted B.E. of Ni2+ and Ni0 is reasonably due to the strong electron-deficient MoOx species that is inclined to grab electron from Ni0 even from Ni2+ species if the surface Ni0 is scarce, being consistent with the previous report [28]. The Mo 3d spectra of NiMo-350-R/SiO2 (R = 400, 500, 600, 650 °C) catalysts as well as the MoO2/SiO2 are shown in Fig. 9B. The fitting peaks at 228.1/231.2, 228.7/231.8, 229.3/232.4, 230.5/233.6 and 232.4/232.5 eV, shows the co-existence of Mo0, Moδ+, Mo4+, Mo5+ and Mo6+ on the catalyst surfaces accordingly [37,49]. When reducing the catalyst at and below 500 °C, the surface Mo6+ is only partly reduced to Mo4+ and Mo5+, and the higher proportion of Mo4+ is observed on the NiMo-350-500/SiO2 catalyst surface than that of the NiMo-350-400/SiO2. When increasing the temperature to and above 500 °C, Mo0 and Moδ+ species are detected due to the generation of MoNi4 and/or Ni2Mo3N alloy (Fig. 1C), in association with the decrease of Mo4+, Mo5+ and Mo6+. Notably, the Mo0 in Ni2Mo3N offers a B.E. of 227.8 eV lower than that (228.1 eV) for the Mo0 in metallic molybdenum [50], indicating electron-rich feature. In addition, the catalyst calcination temperature (from 250 to 650 °C; fixing reduction temperature at 600 °C) has almost no effect on the electron structure of the surface Ni and Mo atoms. It should be pointed out that the amount of surface Ni2+ is enhanced with increasing the calcination temperature (Fig. S4 and Table S3). We also used CO-TPD to probe the interaction between Ni0 and MoOx species. As shown in Fig. 10 , only a very weak peak centered at 780 °C is observed on the MoO2/SiO2, while a broad peak from 350 to 800 °C emerges with strong signal on the Ni/SiO2. Apparently, this observation suggests that the Ni0 sites is mainly responsible for the CO activation. The preferable NiMo-350-600/SiO2 catalyst delivers three CO desorption peaks centered at 310 (α-type COad), 510 (β-type COad) and 685 °C (γ-type COad). In comparison with the Ni/SiO2, the formation of α- and β-type COad species is markedly improved but γ-type COad species is suppressed on the NiMo-350−600/SiO2 catalyst. It is undoubtedly indicated that the addition of Ni provides more sites adjacent with MoOx for CO activation and the co-existence of Ni0 and MoOx weakens the adsorption strength of CO on the Ni0 sites ultimately, in nature, most likely due to the electron-deficiency of Ni0 (i.e., partial electron transfer from Ni to MoOx). In other words, moderately adsorbed CO on Ni0 (such as β-type COad) might be active for subsequent insertion to adsorbed methoxy species. 3.4 Proposed mechanism MoOx species are also likely to provide active sites to adsorb CO, which has been reported by Dumesic’s group [46]. Indeed, MoO2/SiO2 can give a good catalytic performance with a methanol conversion of 2.8 % and an acetyls selectivity of 17.8 % (Table 2) in spite of that CO-TPD results show a poor CO adsorption ability over the MoO2/SiO2. Therefore, we speculate that there might be two pathways to realize methanol carbonylation to acetyls over the MoO2/SiO2: (1) the heterogeneous methanol carbonylation followed a L-H mechanism that methanol and CO were co-adsorbed on the catalyst surface (i.e., methanol and CO was adsorbed on Brønsted acid site of Mo−OH and Lewis acid site of Mon+, respectively); (2) if the E–R mechanism was considered, MoOx species was exclusive to activate methanol, and the gas phase and/or physical adsorbed CO directly attacks the terminal position of adsorbed methoxy species to form the CH3OCO* species, and then to the CH3COO* species via the rearrangement, which is similar to the reported mechanism over ReO4/SiO2 [39]. In fact, the amount of adsorbed CO over the MoO2/SiO2 is quite few and the bonding is too strong (with CO desorption temperature higher than 500 °C) to realize the facile migration and insertion of CO. Therefore, the E–R mechanism speculation is more reasonable for the MoO2/SiO2 catalyst. However, when doping the Ni species, the mechanism over Ni-MoOx/SiO2 may be more likely to follow the L-H mechanism due to the promoted activation and insertion of CO by Ni0 species, which assembles the mechanism of DME carbonylation catalyzed by Rh promoted heteropoly acid [51]. The possible mechanism for methanol carbonylation to acetyls over the Ni-MoOx/SiO2 is displayed in Scheme 1 . 3.5 Catalyst deactivation To investigate the catalyst deactivation, O2 temperature program oxidation (O2-TPO) of the used NiMo-350-600/SiO2 was measured, with profile shown in Fig. S5. It is clear that plenty of COx were detected, suggesting that coke deposition occurred over the NiMo-350-600/SiO2 during the reaction. Although carbon diffraction peaks were undetectable by XRD, it might be in the form of amorphous carbon. Such coke species will gradually cover the active sites and inhibit the contact between reactants and active site, which decreases the conversion and selectivity. 4 Conclusions In summary, the NiMo-C-R/SiO2 catalysts with Ni-MoOx dual-active-site were tailored via H2-reduction of the NiO-MoO3/SiO2 precursors synthesized by stepwise wet-impregnation and subsequent calcination treatment. Over as-obtained NiMo-C-R/SiO2 catalysts, the calcination/reduction temperature dependent conversion/selectivity evolution is observed, which is linked with the Ni-MoOx interaction that is sensitive to the catalyst calcination/reduction temperatures. The characterization results manifest that such catalytic performance relevant Ni-MoOx interaction is mainly reflected in three aspects as follow: (1) high-temperature calcination strengthens the interaction between Ni and MoOx species so that the H spillover from Ni to MoOx apparently facilitates the reduction of MoOx, but lowers the reducibility of NiO in association with a portion of hardly reduced NiMoOx species; (2) Ni doping apparently modifies the acid strength distribution and increases the acid site density, i.e., weak acid site boosts and its strength is weakened with the increased amount of hardly reduced NiMoOx species; (3) the presence of partial electron transfers from Ni0 to MoOx results in a proper adsorption strength of CO on the Ni0 sites, as a result, formation of acetyls is improved and side reactions for DME and hydrocarbons are suppressed reversely. Specifically, Ni-doped MoO2 is paramount for the improvement of acetyls selectivity at promising methanol conversion. This work is a step forward in our understanding of the synergistic catalysis between Ni0 and MoOx species for the gas-phase halide-free methanol carbonylation to acetyls. In spite of the fact that catalyst deactivation is not the focus of this article, it still needs to be studied in the future works to provide directions for designing more efficient and stable methanol carbonylation catalysts. Qiang Nie and Mengchen Shen conducted the material synthesis, characterizations, and catalysis tests. Qiang Nie prepared the original draft. Guofeng Zhao, Ye Liu, and Yong Lu reviewed and editted the manuscript. All authors discussed and commented on the manuscript. Yong Lu directed the research. coredata.dc:description: A promising Ni-MoOx bifunctional catalyst for halide-free methanol carbonylation is developed by H2-reduction of NiO-MoO3/SiO2 obtained via facile impregnation method. Catalyst performance is strongly dependent on the calcination/reduction temperature. Over the preferable NiMo-350-600/SiO2 catalyst obtained by calcining at 350 °C and subsequently reducing at 600 °C, a methanol conversion of 4.2 % and acetyls space-time yield of 1.37 mol kgcat −1 h−1 are achieved with 22.1 % selectivity to acetyls at 290 °C and 3 MPa. Co-existence of Ni0 and MoOx (especially MoO2) markedly decreases formation of dimethyl ether (DME) and reversely increases acetyls formation, in nature, due to the catalyst acidity modulation and the partial electron transfer from Ni0 to MoOx that tunes the CO adsorption strength on Ni0 sites. MoO3 and NiMoO4 are both favorable for formation of acetyls and DME whereas the latter mainly accounts for DME formation. MoNi4 alone favors methyl formate formation while together with MoO2 enhancing DME production.
coredata.dc:title: Ni-MoOx bifunctional catalyst on SiO2 for vapor halide-free methanol carbonylation: Insight into synergistic catalysis between Ni and MoOx
